1 Aims and Scope Molecular Catalysis publishes full papers that are original, rigorous, and scholarly contributions examining the molecular and atomic aspects of catalytic activation and reaction mechanisms. The fields covered are: 1) Heterogeneous catalysis including immobilized catalysts 2) Homogeneous catalysis including organocatalysis, organometallic catalysis, and biocatalysis 3) Theoretical aspects of catalysis The Journal also publishes timely reviews of specialized topics within the scope outlined above; however, prospective authors must obtain preliminary approval from the Editor-in-Chief before preparing a review article. Accepted manuscripts of exceptional quality and substantial interest to the readership may be selected by Editors to feature in the â€˜Editors Choiceâ€™ section of the Journal. It is expected that catalyst activity be appropriately conveyed. Thus, homogeneous systems are ideally characterized by kinetic analysis from which macro- or microscopic rate constants can be presented. Turnover numbers, turnover frequencies, and/or specific activities should be reported as appropriate. For heterogeneous systems, activities should ideally be expressed in turnover frequencies per site or at least per unit area of active component measured using appropriate methods. Extensive use of percent conversion should be avoided. Contributions that do not fall within the above aims and scope will be rejected at the editorial level. Examples are papers that are limited to: 1) Routine preparation and characterization of catalytic materials 2) Routine synthetic organic applications of catalysis Since the scopes of the Elsevier journals Molecular Catalysis, Applied Catalysis A: General, Applied Catalysis B: Environmental, and Catalysis Communications are complementary, an appropriate submission to each journal could be borderline, in which case the advice of another Editor will be sought, possibly redirecting the submission to either Applied Catalysis A: General, Applied Catalysis B: Environmental, or Catalysis Communications (for letters) with the author(s)â€™s agreement. Printed by Henry Ling Ltd, The Dorset Press, Dorchester, UK MOLECULAR CATALYSIS Author benefits: Contributors to Elsevier journals are entitled to a discount on all Elsevier books For a full and complete Guide for Authors, please go to: http://www.elsevier.com/journals/Molecular Catalysis/2468-8231/ guide-for-authors (Contents continued from outside back cover) (Contents continued on back matter) 115042 Morphology control of Ni(OH) 2 -TiO 2 nanosheet array and its excellent electrochemical hydrogen evolution performance Fen Â Qiao , Changshun Â Zheng , Jikang Â Zhao , Jiaxin Â Zhou and Genxiang Â Wang Ni(OH) 2 -TiO 2 composites were successfully synthesized on nickel foam (NF) via a two-step hydrothermal method to address the kinetic challenge in hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during water electrolysis. By optimizing nickel source concentration and reaction conditions, the composites exhibited exceptional morphology and structure. SEM, XRD, and XPS analyses confirmed increased specific surface area and abundant active sites, facilitating electron transport and diffusion. The optimized Ni(OH) 2 -TiO 2 /NF catalyst achieved an overpotential of 63 mV at 10 mAÂ·cm âˆ’2 with a lower Tafel slope, higher double layer capacitance, and excellent reaction kinetics. DFT studies revealed charge transfer from Ni(OH) 2 to TiO 2 , optimizing charge distribution and reducing activation energy. This study offers new strategies for developing low-cost, high-performance transition metal-based HER catalysts. 115037 Zn-TiO 2 /AC photocatalysts for pollutants degradation from experimental and DFT studies Xiao Â Chu , Chen Â Chen , Ying Â Liang , Yuliang Â Chen , Yuliang Â Wu , Yijiang Â Liu , Rui Â Meng , Wenmin Â Wang , Weiwei Â Huang , Fei Â Yang , Xuesong Â Yi and Jun Â Cheng 115050 The ring-opening polymerization of cyclic ester and carbonate catalyzed by trimethyl glycine and catalyst design: A DFT study Shuang Â Li , Xiaowei Â Xu , Ziqiang Â Li , Lijuan Â Ding , Ying Â Peng , Xiaohui Â Kang and Yi Â Luo 115023 In-situ controlled synthesis of BiOI/Bi 2 S 3 Z-scheme heterostructure with enriched oxygen vacancies for efficient photocatalytic removal of hexavalent chromium Meng Â Lan , Xiaoli Â Dong , Nan Â Zheng and Yujun Â Liu The BiOI/Bi 2 S 3 Z-scheme in-situ heterostructure photocatalyst with abundant oxygen vacancies was constructed by in situ vulcanization strategy using BiOI as a precursor and applied for the efficient elimination of Cr(VI). g to proofs, should be directed to: Molecular Catalysis, Elsevier Ireland Limited, Elsevier House, Brookvale Place, East Park, Shannon, Co.
